abstract: A Boolean value that indicates whether the view receives more than one touch at a time.
overview:
## Discussion

When set to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true], the view receives all touches associated with a multi-touch sequence and starting within the view’s bounds. When set to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false], the view receives only the first touch event in a multi-touch sequence that start within the view’s bounds. The default value of this property is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false].

Other views in the same window can still receive touch events when this property is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false]. If you want this view to handle multi-touch events exclusively, set the values of both this property and the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIView/isExclusiveTouch] property to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true]. This property does not prevent a view from being asked to handle multiple touches. For example, two subviews may both forward their touches to a common parent, such as a window or the root view of a view controller. This property determines how many touches initially targeting the view are delivered to that view.

# isMultipleTouchEnabled

**Instance Property**

A Boolean value that indicates whether the view receives more than one touch at a time.

## Declaration

```swift
@MainActor var isMultipleTouchEnabled: Bool { get set }
```

## Discussion

When set to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true], the view receives all touches associated with a multi-touch sequence and starting within the view’s bounds. When set to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false], the view receives only the first touch event in a multi-touch sequence that start within the view’s bounds. The default value of this property is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false].



Other views in the same window can still receive touch events when this property is [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/false]. If you want this view to handle multi-touch events exclusively, set the values of both this property and the [doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIView/isExclusiveTouch] property to [doc://com.apple.documentation/documentation/Swift/true]. This property does not prevent a view from being asked to handle multiple touches. For example, two subviews may both forward their touches to a common parent, such as a window or the root view of a view controller. This property determines how many touches initially targeting the view are delivered to that view.

## Configuring the event-related behavior

- **isUserInteractionEnabled**: A Boolean value that determines whether user events are ignored and removed from the event queue.
- **isExclusiveTouch**: A Boolean value that indicates whether the receiver handles touch events exclusively.
